txanleitung: [DF]{LANGSUPPORT}1. Enable the checkbox {txgpsauto} to automatically update your location during use. ({txgpsbutton} determines your current position once and stores it.) Nothing more is required for now. – For higher accuracy see {quotes|0-}4. {txshowagni-}{quotes|1-}.[~LF][~LF]Alternatively, you may enter a place name or an address into the text field (if supported by your device) or coordinates (e.g. 50.94, 6.96). A 3rd and 4th entry are optional: approximate altitude &bl;m], approximate temperature at twilight &bl;°C]. Then enable the checkbox {txwelcomescr}. – When basic data are changed, {txsunclock-} performs a daily calculation which may take between 1[NDASH]30 seconds depending on the device.[~LF][~LF]2. {txshowclock} displays a digital clock at the upper right of the dial. {txuhrsinn} defines whether the clock runs clockwise (south) or counter-clockwise: when changing the direction of rotation, the part of the solar circle below the horizon is positioned in front of you (details see next page).
txmore: [DF]3. {txnachtmodus} {txlangarr|auto-} switches at sunset, at −6° until the end of twilight, +6° before it. {txfarben} selects different dials.[~LF][~LF]4. {txfullscr} prevents the screen from turning off and switches to full screen. {txweathapi} overlays a forecast on the clock (see below, network required). {txagnihotra} shows markers for the solar hand as well as the time of the next solar zero crossing & countdown. Six minutes before Agnihotra the display is enlarged and seconds are shown (⁺ = GPS current). – If your settings are not applied, tap the refresh button at the lower right of the dial.[~LF][~LF]You can zoom into the dial using two fingers (or triple tap). To move the zoomed image, do so slowly. Fast movements swipe to the next page. – On the next page you will find an explanation of the dial.[DF]

txlegende0: [b]–– Explanations:[/b][~LF][~LF]The lunar date works like our date, but with nights instead of days: Μx·y (p/z), with x = lunar “month” of the year, y = night of the lunar month. Μ1 is the first full moon of the light year. As lunar months vary in length, z gives the total nights of the lunar month, p the Full Moon night. The night ends at sunrise.[~LF][~LF]The light-year season divides the year into eight phases of increasing and decreasing daylight: 1. {solcal_lph|0-} ({solcal_dat0}, see also Imbolc), 2a. {solcal_lph|1-} ({solcal_dat1}, see also Lixia), 2b. {solcal_lph|2-} ({solcal_dat2}), 2c. {solcal_lph|3-} ({solcal_dat3}), 3. {solcal_lph|4-} ({solcal_dat4}), 4a. {solcal_lph|5-} ({solcal_dat5}), 4b. {solcal_lph|6-} ({solcal_dat6}) and 4c. {solcal_lph|7-} ({solcal_dat7}). Short form: Ϟx·y (x = phase, y = progress in[SP]%). Dates are determined astronomically and shift from year to year.[DF][DF][DF]
txanleitung2: [DF]{txgordonssunclock} is essentially a single-hand clock with a dial that changes daily, oriented to the rhythms of nature and the celestial bodies. It shows the position of the Sun and the starry sky. A new kind of time display that is not artificial like our conventional clock (with railway time and daylight saving time), but moves in harmony with the seasons.[~LF][~LF][i]NOTE: You can swipe back and forth between this guide and the dial.[/i][~LF][~LF][~LF][b]–– Your view:[/b][~LF][~LF]In the centre of the screen you see a horizontal line. This is the horizon (the Earth's surface). The pointed triangle in the middle is a spruce tree that you see from a distance (or a church). You are not looking down at it from above, but standing in front of it.[~LF][~LF]If you have not changed anything in the settings ({quotes|0-}{txuhrsinn-}: {txlangarr|auto-}{quotes|1-}), you are usually facing south in the Northern Hemisphere (north in the Southern Hemisphere). Objects on the left of the screen are in the east, on the right in the west (reversed in the Southern Hemisphere). The respective cardinal directions are shown at the edge of the horizon.[~LF][~LF]The lighter band below the horizon indicates civil twilight. The large dark grey area symbolises the night (including nautical twilight). Objects located in this area are not visible.[~LF][~LF]At the top right you see the local time (optional), the altitude of the Sun in degrees in the sky (e.g. 27.6°), as well as your position as a numerical code (e.g. {quotes|0-}cri-hs{quotes|1-}) or a place name if you have entered one. Below that the light season and the unequal temporal hour display.
txanleitung2b: [DF][DF][b]–– Sun:[/b][~LF][~LF]The sun (at the end of the clock’s single hand) moves during the day from left to right (reversed in the Southern Hemisphere). The farther left the sun is on the screen, the more it is in the east; the farther right, the more it is in the west (reversed in the Southern Hemisphere). The higher the sun appears on the screen, the higher it is in the sky.[~LF][~LF]The sun follows the drawn circular path on which it moves within a day. At the edge of the circular path, hours are shown (e.g. „12“ o’clock), so the circular path also functions as a dial.[~LF][~LF]On the dial, for example, you can see how the numbers shift during daylight saving time, while the circular path remains the same. Or: how legal time in most places deviates from local solar time, because 12 o’clock is not exactly at the top of the dial. Temporal hours do it differently: at the 12th hour (12ἡ) it is always sunset.[~LF][~LF][~LF][b]–– Moon:[/b][~LF][~LF]The moon also has a circular path, drawn in light grey. Since the moon needs more than 24 hours for one revolution, 1.5 hours from the previous day are appended in extra light grey. If you „live with the clock“, you can clearly see how the moon winds higher and lower over 27 days. You can also observe how, at full moon, it stands opposite the sun in the circular position (far away); at new moon, however, it is at the same circular position (close to the sun). It is usually not exactly the same position because the view is from the side (not from above). It is exactly the same position only during a solar eclipse.[~LF][~LF]Full moon and new moon are marked by shadows. New moon is shown for 35 hours (because that is the time during which you cannot see the moon at all). Full moon is shown for 24 hours. The recalculation of the sun and moon paths takes place each day at UTC 00:00.
txanleitung2c: [DF][DF][b]–– Planets:[/b][~LF][~LF]The five planets visible to the naked eye are shown, with photos as you would see them through binoculars, or (depending on the design) represented by their astronomical symbols (see previous page). If you look at the real night sky, you can distinguish planets from stars by knowing that planets do not twinkle but shine steadily. They appear noticeably larger in the sky than the far-away stars and are therefore not influenced as strongly by fluctuations in atmospheric density.[~LF][~LF][~LF][b]–– Stars:[/b][~LF][~LF]In addition, the ten brightest stars are shown, symbolized by a letter in a square (legend see previous page). While the planets stay relatively orderly, mostly more or less near the sun’s path, the path of the stars is independent of the sun – after all, they are their own sun. In the star symbols, two sides of the square are always drawn more strongly than the other two. This indicates the corner or quadrant of their path in which they are currently located. If the highlighted corner is at the bottom right, the star is (more or less) at the „end“ of its path downwards and to the right. In its further movements it will mainly move upwards and to the left (often also outside the screen). If the top side is stronger, the star is in front of you; if the bottom side is stronger, behind you (if you have not changed the rotation direction).
txanleitung2d: [DF][DF][b]–– Weather:[/b][~LF][~LF]A local weather forecast can be displayed in the lower left corner (details on previous page). It presents the character of the day in a measured way using symbols: e.g. {wx/rain} indicates actual rain (6[NDASH]18 h), not occasional drizzle (similarly: {wx/rain2} heavy rain, {wx/snow} snow, {wx/uncertain} uncertain, {wx/dry} dry, {wx/sun} sunny, {wx/sun2} plenty of sun, {wx/still} calm, {wx/wind} windy, {wx/storm} storm, {wx/storm2} severe storm). No symbol means unremarkable weather.[~LF][~LF][~LF][b]–– History:[/b][~LF][~LF]{txgordonssunclock} is the result of more than twenty years of engagement with the representation of time. The starting point was a mechanical organ clock with a 24 h dial and a month-dependent display of sunrise and sunset. From this emerged the concept of a {txsunclock-}, initially as a feasibility study and an ePaper wall clock; later, weather display and GPS were added. The idea of a location-flexible version culminated in this Android app.[~LF][~LF]The goal of the development is a representation of time that follows the course of the Sun and the natural daily and annual cycles – as a reconnection of humans with nature and with our inner, circadian time. May it provide insight and understanding.[DF][DF][DF]
txanleitung3: [DF]This software is a free, private project. Please use it as it is. In principle, no personal data is collected or transmitted. No internet connection is required for operation. Details on optional features (weather display, place name resolution), error reports, and update checks can be found in the privacy policy.[DF][DF]
